narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basics of functional analysis - Hahn Banach, weak topology, open mapping/closed graph theorems, Riesz-Frechet, compact operators, etc. Pretty cool stuff overall. For prospective students - 320 is definitely skippable as a prereq; plenty of people took this class without it and are doing fine.
Basics of functional analysis - topological vector spaces, banach spaces, weak topologies, hilbert spaces, spectral theory

An introduction to functional analysis, with a broad survey of different applications. From the course description: "We will define topological vector spaces and study maps between them, including the Open Mapping and Closed Graph Theorems and the Uniform Boundedness Principle.  We will then study consequences of (local) convexity, including the Hahn-Banach theorem.  We will discuss duality in Banach spaces and the associated weak-* topology, and study the associated geometry.  We will finally study bounded normal operators on Hilbert space, their spectra, and the associated spectral theorem and functional calculus."

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Tom is fantastic. The material is also fundamentally interesting, and easily applicable to a number of non-math fields. 

Weaknesses: None, beyond the standard "everyone who took a gap year is smarter than me" regret that Zoom lectures are apt to induce.
Not really any weaknesses - it was a great introduction to the core concepts of functional analysis.

Material was well taught and grading was reasonable. Though often there would be critical typos in the homework or we would need random lemmas/theorems that we hadn't covered (so these aspects could be improved).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely worth taking. It's fairly accessible (no need to take 320 beforehand), and it feels like a big payoff for whatever analysis courses you may have taken prior. Honestly, it's absurd how powerful some of the theorems you learn are - proving Hahn-Banach on the first day of class is like starting a Pokemon game with a Level 100 Arceus.

Yes. If you haven't functional analysis before, or, if you're like me, and have very shaky point-set topology, this course would be really good to take. Various forms of vector space + topology appear everywhere throughout mathematics, and this course definitely gives you some very useful tools to deal with them.
Yes, the subject material is fantastic and beautiful at times. It is well worth the challenge, but make sure that you are prepared for the time investment.
